ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I enhanced my conversational skills, grammatical knowledge, and vocabulary through this course. I also got a lot more practice with presenting in ASL, which is a very good skill to have.

Through this course, I was able to apply my foundational ASL skills through the homework assignments and presentations. I became more comfortable with formal presentations and presenting and creating ASL literature.

I learned the parameters of Deaf literature and how to create my own pieces of Deaf literature in a way that authentically showcases Deaf culture and performing arts. This course continued my studies of sign language with a focus on more intricate levels of communication beyond sign formation.
lots of conversational and presentational ASL

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is a great course, as all the ASL classes are. It has good content and pacing, but it also has a heavier workload than L1-3. Since I don't think this increased work really improved my knowledge of the language, it was a bit frustrating at times to have such long assignments. We also had more assignments than the other class, so it would definitely be an improvement to have the classes standardized.
The strengths of this course is the multitude of opportunities we get to apply our foundational knowledge and the feedback we receive.

I really enjoyed the content of the course and its many opportunities to practice communicating in sign. Learning about Deaf literature truly was fascinating. I think the only way this course could be improved is if the syllabus were a little more clearly structured. Towards the middle and end of the semester I lost track of the learning objectives and when one topic ended and another began.

strengths: took a more holistic, cultural approach to understanding Deaf culture as part of ASL
weaknesses: INCREDIBLY disorganized (sometimes given less than a day to complete HW assignments, create presentations, memorize and film content, do incredibly long journals assignments, etc). I really loved ASL through L2 but felt like at the higher levels especially, the classes are a bit of a mess. Also felt like the expectations for hours/projects outside of class were not reasonable; it almost felt like they assumed we take no other classes outside of ASL. I really wish my experience was better and that the dept took a more organized approach to teaching/assigning things bc I otherwise would have loved it so I'm hoping they are clearer with students moving forward.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend the course, but I would be careful about what instructor you pick. The instructor can really make or break the class environment and your stress level.
Yes, this class has a great opportunity to build ASL presentation skills and get more comfortable signing.

I absolutely would. I believe that in this course more than others the emphasis on Deaf culture and Deaf literature really contributed to my understanding of ASL and the Deaf community. I think this course is a great next step for those interested in continuing their study of ASL and Deaf culture.
